ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Assignments throughout the week
We had live virtual lectures three times a week, plus additional non-synchronous assignments and group activities.
We met synchronously three times a week in a small seminar format with breakout rooms. On the two days we were asynchronous we watched recorded mini lectures and read informational packets/files.
We met in a seminar-based format on M-W-F, and completed other course work (not live) on T-Th.
out of class group work.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about ASL glossing, other signing systems, and Deaf culture.
I got much better at ASL!
proficient in ASL!
I learnt a lot about glossing in ASL, Deaf culture, and expanded my vocabulary.

I gained so much by taking this course! After ASL 110 and 120, I still did not feel confident in my ability to have conversations in ASL, but ASL 130 has boosted my confidence and given me lots of practice/practical knowledge regarding ASL. We learned how to gloss, which is something we haven't learned in a previous ASL class here at Yale. We learned how to put together grammar components, vocabulary, and topics of Deaf culture to become well-rounded, proficient ASL students.
fluency in ASL. Learned more about the grammar

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was filled with non-synchronous group activities, which took up time that could have been used conversationally signing. Grammar lessons and culture discussions also could have been signed, but we were required to write them instead. Additionally, though we only met for 50 minutes three times a week, we spent more than half the time in breakout rooms.
love Casey so much!!

Strengths: frequent meetings keeps the language fresh in your brain, our small groups were amazingly helpful, and the amount of content presented visually on canvas was great. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes it was hard to understand signs I didn't know or were variations of signs previously learnt and fingerspelling is still difficult. Signing a bit slower would improve this.

There were so many strengths! Casey was one of them - the only reason this semester was as awesome as it was is because we had a great professor! The weekly 'vlogs' completed with our groups as well as our ENP's were open-ended, allowing us to sign about things that interested us - which definitely aided in my ability to understand the material. There were plenty of opportunities for practice/instruction, whether it be from our 3x-week Zoom meetings, our group Zoom meetings, or even one-on-one meetings with Casey. The class was super organized, which is always great in a language class, as the work can often get confusing and overwhelming. One weakness was the amount of work. Although the smaller, weekly vocabulary and grammar assignments weren't long or difficult, they sometimes felt a little tedious to complete every week.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Small group work was a great success and technological barriers can't necessarily be improved during the pandemic. This course would be much better in person, but it is possible to come away with great knowledge even online.

I really appreciated that this class wasn't every day as it would have been in person. It was really nice to have less time on Zoom, as well as the additional time to do coursework in the empty time slots. Casey was also super flexible about attendance and late assignments and was constantly making class time to check-in with everyone and see how we're doing.

I think ASL is always going to be challenging to teach over the internet and not in-person. It was sometimes hard to do group assignments because of the barrier of not being physically together, but Casey was great with changing expectations of assignments based on the fact that we were all trying to work together while being separated.
I think online works pretty well with this class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Learning ASL provides students with a new means of expressing themselves, and allows hearing individuals to develop a greater appreciation for Deaf culture.
Yes! ASL is awesome and Casey is a fantastic teacher.
YES. YES. YES. I LOVE CASEY AND KRISTEN SO MUCH!! Such an amazing course. SO much fun.
Definitely! ASL is an amazing language that I recommend any student learn. You will improve your visual processing skills and learn a new language with amazing peers and professors.

DEFINITELY! If you ever get the chance to take ASL 130, especially with Casey, DO IT! You will not regret it! Casey is a great instructor who took the time to both teach AND have fun with us - whether it be directly related to the class or not. I was excited to go to class every other day, and I looked forward to getting to work on my video assignments every week. If you are dedicated to getting your work done and paying attention in the Zoom meetings as well as the asynchronous work, this class will be very manageable, and Casey always provided clear feedback on what I was doing well and what I could improve on. It was a vast difference from ASL 120, where I often felt I didn't understand what I was getting points off for. Long story short, 10/10 would reccomend!
yes! very great course.
